intro: Prenanthes sororia, commonly known as the common water dropwort, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to North America. It typically grows in moist to wet habitats such as stream banks, marshes, and wet meadows. The plant has slender, upright stems that are often tinged with red, and its leaves are alternate, lance-shaped, and have a distinctive waxy coating. The small, greenish-white flowers are clustered in umbels and bloom in late summer. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its aromatic foliage and unique ecological role in wetland ecosystems.
